This document represents the updated and revised Risk Management Plan (RMP) for the Pleasant Grove Agriform Farm Supply Facility operated by The Tremont Group, Inc., located at 4036 Pleasant Grove Road in Pleasant Grove, California. The Facility is an existing operating source. This document has been prepared in order to address the following issues:

* Acknowledge the operation of an existing source with processes subject to the RMP regulations and requirements.

* Incorporate revisions to the RMP pursuant to the requirements of the CalARP and 40 CFR 68 regulations.

The RMP addresses the requirements of the California Accidental Release Program (CalARP) as adopted by the State of California as outlined in California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 19. These federal and state requirements build upon the provisions of the ?general duty clause? of the Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990, and the federal RMP program requirements in 40 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) 68, which require the following activities of all facilities which produce, process, store, or handle listed substances:

* Identify hazards,

* Design and maintain a safe facility,

* Prevent releases,

* Minimize the consequences of releases.

The required approach to accomplishing the above, pursuant to the CalARP and Federal RMP regulations, is to have a documented Risk Management Plan, which outlines the steps and procedures a facility must take to prevent and mitigate accidental releases. The Tremont Group, Inc. has chosen to prepare and implement its RMP for the storage and handling of aqua ammonia and regulated pesticides, in order to fulfill its obligations with respect to the RMP regulations and the General Duty clause and to protect its employees and the surrounding community from the effects of accidental releases.

Pursuant to 40 CFR 68.155 and CCR Title 19, Section 2745.3, the following summary is given:

Facility Description and Regulated Substances

The primary activity at the Pleasant Gro

ve Facility is the storage and sale of fertilizers, in addition to, the sale of pre-packaged agricultural chemicals to agricultural operations in the Sacramento Delta Area of Northern California.  The Pleasant Grove Facility handles aqua ammonia as the nitrogen source for fertilizer. Aqua ammonia is stored in two 11,000-gallon above ground tanks at the Facility.  The storage tanks are located within a secondary containment structure.  The maximum quantity of aqua ammonia handled at the facility is 165,000 pounds. The total quantity of ammonia present in aqua ammonia, based on 25% active ingredient by weight is 41,250 lbs.

Substance Used/Stored: Aqua Ammonia  (CAS# 7664-41-7) Max. Qty: 165,000 lbs

Facility SIC: 5191    NAICS Code: 42491 Concentration: 25 wt%



Several regulated pesticides are stored at the Pleasant Grove facility warehouse.  All pesticides are stored with like or compatible materials based on the product labels and Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDSs).  Quantities of regulated pesticides at the Facility fluctuate daily as shipments are received and sales made of pesticides.  The materials are stored in the original manufacturer?s packaging which includes 30-gallon drums or cylinders, 2.5-gallon plastic bottles, 1-gallon, plastic bottles in cardboard boxes, and bags of varying sizes.  Pesticides containing regulated substances are not blended or repackaged at the Facility.  Worst-case and alternative release scenarios for pesticides were not modeled for this RMP.  

The accidental release prevention and emergency action policies at the facility are delineated in Sections 3.0 and 11.0 respectively. A brief description of the prevention and emergency response policies is as follows.

Accident Prevention Program Policies and Elements

The accident prevention program is implemented through an established set of policies and programs including, but not limited to, the following:

* Inspection and maintenance program for all system equipment

* Monitoring of

employee and contractor use of the systems

* Emergency Response Plan

* Lockout/Tagout Procedures and Program

* Employee Safety Training Program

* Compilation of substance information (MSDS)

* Incident investigation procedures

* Periodic compliance audits

* Compliance with all applicable laws, ordinances, and regulations.

Integral parts of the prevention program are found in the following plans:

Hazardous Materials Business Plan ? Injury and Illness Prevention Plan ? Spill Containment Control and Countermeasure Plan ? Hazardous Waste Storage and Handling Procedures ? Hazard Communication Program ? Fire Protection and Prevention Procedures ? Hearing Conservation Program ? Respiratory Conservation Program ? Electrical Safety Program ? Proposition 65 Compliance Program ? Forklift and Industrial Truck Program.

These plans are kept on site for inspection during normal business hours.

Emergency Action Policies and Elements

The emergency response program is implemented through an established set of policies and programs including, but not limited to, the following:

* Establishment of criteria defining an emergency

* Staff training and responsibility assignments

* Emergency notification procedures (on and off-site)

* Evacuation procedures

* Written emergency response procedures

* Coordination of emergency response with local authorities

* Incident investigation and follow-up procedures 

Release Scenario Data

The ammonia tanks are located outside in a secondary containment. As such, no passive mitigation factor was used in the worst-case ammonia emissions calculations and impact analyses. For aqueous ammonia, the unloading hose, per facility estimates, is approximately 3.0 inch in diameter (ID) and 30 feet long. The volume of the unloading hose was calculated and then doubled to account for additional drainage losses. This loss was assumed to completely evaporate over the 10 minute time period. Rupture of the unloading hose would also occur outside of th

e secondary containment area, therefore no passive mitigation factor was applied to this scenario.  No outside individuals or sensitive receptors would be affected in the effect of a release.

The piping and distribution network for aqua ammonia is equipped with a number of manual and automatic valves, which effectively limit the amount and duration of any accidental release. In addition, the tank areas are equipped with emergency eyewash and safety showers.  The pesticides are stored within a warehouse, which will contain a liquid release of pesticide and control the dispersion.

The general accidental release prevention program is comprised of the following elements:

* Proper maintenance of all system equipment.

* Proper operation of all system equipment.

* Internal operating policies with respect to ammonia tank capacity.

* Comprehensive personnel training.

* A written emergency response plan.

* A written hazardous materials management plan.

* Documented safety procedures for employees and contractors.

* Inclusion of ammonia specific health, safety, and response data in the RMP.

The facility is an existing source and has not experienced an accidental release of ammonia or any other hazardous substance in the last 5 years.

The current emergency response plan and procedures for The Tremont Group are discussed in detail in Section 10.0 and Appendix A. The local fire department will be the first responder in an ammonia emergency.  Tremont Group personnel will perform "awareness" duties only, which simply means that once the ammonia spill or release is discovered, Tremont Group personnel will make the proper notifications and set the emergency procedures in motion. In the event of a major release, The Tremont Group may join forces with the fire department and State/County OES personnel in a "unified command effort" until the emergency has been mitigated.

Chemical Specific Prevention Elements

Chemical specific prevention measures are summarized as follows:

* Periodic inspection of ammonia tank, containment area, pumps, and piping network.

* Monitoring of ammonia storage tank and system pressures and temperatures.

* Monitoring of unloading/delivery procedures.

* Provide all required safety and response equipment.

* Provide a chemical specific training program.

* Access to The Tremont Group Pleasant Grove Facility is controlled, and the facility is fenced.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

    Presently, The Tremont Group is operating a number of similar facilities in Northern California. Data developed from the operational experience at these facilities will be directly applied to the operation and safety aspects of the Pleasant Grove facility, and vice versa. Operational and safety issues identified at any Tremont Group facility are immediately analyzed for applicability to other operational sites. 

The facility will constantly strive for improved performance and reliability from all its processes. As specific process and safety improvements are identified they will be evaluated by staff for application and implementation.

Training

The facility staff, as well as The Tremont Group corporate staff, understands that incidents involving the accidental release of listed substances can be reduced and/or eliminated by having trained operations and maintenance staff. A training program, which incorporates specific operating procedures and safe work practices, is an essential element of an effective prevention program.

The current training program is comprised of the following:

* Initial employee training

* Periodic re-training and certification

* Training provided as a result of a new equipment addition or modification per the RMP Change Management (RMPCM)

* Refresher training

* Training records for each employee

Mechanical Integrity

The mechanical integrity element of the facility operations procedures ensures that new and modified equipment or processes are manufactured to meet process requirements, that the

y are installed correctly, and subsequently maintained in safe operating condition. 

The facility?s mechanical integrity system is contained within the system operation and maintenance manuals. The system manuals delineate such practices as:

* Equipment or process inspection techniques and frequency

* Preventative maintenance schedules

* Maintenance requirements and procedures

* History of maintenance

* Process identification, model numbers, and serial numbers

* Maintenance logs (who performed the maintenance, and information on the maintenance activity, etc.)

In addition, the program contains the following elements:

* Written maintenance, testing, and inspection procedures and schedules.

* Maintenance training.

* Maintenance documentation.

* Deficiency correction procedures and documentation.

* New equipment quality assurance procedures.

Incident Investigations

Thorough investigation of ?incidents? (any occurrence that results in or could result in catastrophic releases of ammonia or regulated pesticides) or ?near misses? (any situation where conditions existed under which an incident could have occurred, but did not) is another essential element of the RMP program. Incident investigations typically yield perspectives on equipment or process safety that are not normally apparent to plant operations and maintenance staff, such as:

* Incident ?causes? outside of the PHA scope.

* Was the facility response appropriate?

* Did the Emergency Response Plan (ERP) function as designed?

* Did the ERP and RMP provide the necessary level of protection with respect to the offsite impacts?

* What changes need to be made to the RMP and ERP to ensure an appropriate response in the future?

Incident investigations pursuant to this RMP will be specific to ammonia and pesticide process systems. The following data is typically gathered by the incident investigation team subsequent to the incident:

* Date and time of the ?incident? or ?near miss?

* Timeliness of in

cident report to the responding agency

* Timeliness of public awareness and/or evacuation measures

* Description of the incident or ?near miss?

* An evaluation of the events that resulted in the incident or ?near miss?

* Recommendations to prevent future occurrences of the incident

The incident investigation policy is delineated in the safety procedures. The investigation results, including the implementation of all recommendations, are reviewed with facility staff whose job responsibilities are relevant to the findings. Copies of the investigation reports are maintained on site for a minimum of five years, and are used during the periodic PHA re-evaluations.

RMP Change Management

Operational, safety, and environmental issues must be addressed whenever a change occurs at a facility, which involves an affected process or substance. Quite often a change made in one aspect of the process may affect other parts of the process due to facility system integration. Such changes must be reviewed prior to initiation, to ensure that they do not compromise the operational safety and integrity of the process, and to minimize adverse effects to worker safety and public health. The facility RMPCM procedures are used to evaluate all changes to the following types of systems:

* Process chemicals (delivery, storage, handling)

* Control technology systems (operation rates, chemicals used, by-products or wastes produced)

* Equipment design and construction

* Operations and maintenance procedures

* Other changes to facility equipment or processes

The current RMPCM procedures, developed by The Tremont Group and Pleasant Grove facility staff, are used for the Pleasant Grove facility to track changes in equipment or processes as identified or planned by facility personnel. Facility staff evaluate the potential impact(s) of the change on operational safety and worker health via a checklist for minor changes or a design review for major changes. The following steps are taken to

ensure the safe implementation of the change.

* Prior to startup, process safety information is updated as required. Revised process safety information is placed in the operations, safety, and maintenance manuals.

* Operating procedures are revised in accordance with the new or modified equipment or process design and operations specifications. Updated procedures are placed in the appropriate operations, safety, and maintenance manuals.

* Employees affected by the change (job classification basis) receive training in accordance with the specific training program prior to startup of the process. The employees training records are updated.
